pull.title: test: Switch multiprocess to clang i686 build
pull.body:
Building for i686 with clang helps to catch bugs early for:
* The OSS-Fuzz i686 clang libFuzzer build
* The arm 32-bit native clang build

Fixes  #22889

issue.title: Compiling fails on 32-bit systems
issue.body:
Since #20233 compiling with clang 10.0 fails:
```
bench/addrman.cpp:113:32: error: non-constant-expression cannot be narrowed from type 'unsigned long long' to 'size_t' (aka 'unsigned int') in initializer list [-Wc++11-narrowing]
    const size_t addrman_count{bench.epochs() * bench.epochIterations()};
                               ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
bench/addrman.cpp:113:32: note: insert an explicit cast to silence this issue
    const size_t addrman_count{bench.epochs() * bench.epochIterations()};
                               ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
                               static_cast<size_t>(                    )
1 error generated.
make[2]: *** [Makefile:12508: bench/bench_bitcoin-addrman.o] Error 1
```

events.message: ci: Switch multiprocess to i686 build

events.body:
Great!

CI catches #22889.

Now add a [fix](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/22889#issuecomment-915233676)?

rename.from: ci: Switch multiprocess to clang i686 build
rename.to: test: Switch multiprocess to clang i686 build

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -6,11 +6,12 @@
 
 export LC_ALL=C.UTF-8
 
-export CONTAINER_NAME=ci_native_multiprocess
+export HOST=i686-pc-linux-gnu
+export CONTAINER_NAME=ci_i686_multiprocess
 export DOCKER_NAME_TAG=ubuntu:20.04
-export PACKAGES="cmake python3 python3-pip llvm clang"
-export DEP_OPTS="DEBUG=1 MULTIPROCESS=1"
+export PACKAGES="cmake python3 python3-pip llvm clang g++-multilib"
+export DEP_OPTS="DEBUG=1 MULTIPROCESS=1 CC='clang -m32' CXX='clang++ -m32'"
comments.body: I believe this won't work due to #22184.

comments.body: It should still compile successfully. Though, I removed it now to minimize the diff

comments.body:
> It should still compile successfully.

Yes, it should. But with gcc, not clang.
